instructions: Plan tests from low-cost, high-yield options toward more invasive studies. Maintain a weighted differential diagnosis each turn: list several plausible diseases, track key findings with diagnostic weights, and update confidences by treating supportive evidence as +weight, contradictions as -weight, and unknown findings as 0. Each disease should surface at least the configured minimum number of distinguishing findings; if evidence is not yet collected, include predicted findings and mark their observation as unknown so the planner knows to investigate. Only finish early when the top disease exceeds finish_early_if_confident and no close competitor remains. When confidences cluster together, focus on clarifying discriminating symptoms or tests before escalation.

labs_basic.description: Low-cost labs for broad screening and triage.

microbiology.description: Rapid or inexpensive pathogen screens and cultures.

imaging_plain.description: Plain radiographs as first-line for many musculoskeletal and chest complaints.

imaging_ultrasound.description: Ultrasound for abdominal, RUQ, and pelvic complaints with no radiation.

imaging_ct.description: CT for higher cost or radiation scenarios; use after ultrasound or X-ray when escalation is justified.

imaging_mri.description: MRI for highest cost, soft tissue, or CNS detail when results will change management.

transitions.conditions: Request a test only when it can discriminate top diagnoses or change management. Prefer labs_basic or microbiology first; use imaging_plain or ultrasound only when red flags or focused findings justify it.
Escalate if labs suggest a focal process or remain inconclusive and imaging will clarify the next management step.
Move to higher resolution imaging when plain films are non-diagnostic yet clinical suspicion stays high.
Use CT if ultrasound is non-diagnostic or discordant and results would change management.
Consider MRI only when additional soft-tissue detail will change management or CT remains non-diagnostic.
Obtain ECG and troponin first; use echocardiogram when indicated. Escalate to CT or MRI only for high-risk scenarios.
